He has also been elected as his village's vice chief. Mr. P. plans to use his portion of this loan to raise his farm's output by improving the productivity of his soil and combating insects. He will also use some of the loan to pay school fees for his three childR.. His wife, Mrs. Vet Yen, contributes to the family income by working as a nurse.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and pesticide

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Byambasuren S., 40, is married and lives with her husband and two daughters in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a house and both of her daughters attend local secondary school. 

Her husband works with her to operate her animal rawhides trading business, which she started in 2000. They own a car that they use to collect raw materials from the countryside and at the local market. 

She is a hardworking and modest person who says that she wants to make more profit and buy a new car to use for her business. She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to buy more animal rawhides and increase her working capital.

loans.use: To buy more animal rawhides

loans.name: Mr. Phaung Lorn Village Bank Group

texts.en: This loan group is made up of thirteen people, all of whom live in Traeuy Tonloab village in Takeo province. Each will use a portion of the loan to generate more income by expanding a small business. Mr. Phaung L. has been selected to lead this group by all of its members. He and his wife, Mrs. San Em, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land where they grow rice and vegetables to sell. Their field has some problems because the soil is not very fertile. To improve his farm's output, Mr. Phaung L. will use his portion of this loan to buy fertilizer. He and his wife have two children, one of whom is employed in garment factory, while the other works as a laborer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Jigjidsuren

texts.en: Jigjidsuren, 36, married and lives with his wife and four children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All his four children attend school. He operates a grocery trading business with his wife which they started in 2007. They buy grocery products from the local market and sell them to herders who live in the countryside, far from the city. They own a car which is very useful for their business. He is a hard-working and active person who says, "I would like to buy a new car and expand my business activities." He is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to buy more food to sell to the countryside people.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Kann

texts.en: Mrs. Kann T. is married and lives in Trapeang Chhuk village, which is located in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land where she supports her family by growing rice. She also runs a business on the side selling floor mats. Her husband, Mr. Bun Thoeun Ya, works in construction in Phnom Penh city, which is quite far from their home. In order to see her husband more often, she has applied for a loan to buy a new motorbike. She and her husband have three children, two of whom attend the local public school. Their youngest child is not yet old enough to go to school.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Yeth

texts.en: Mrs. Yeth K. is a married woman born in 1959 and living in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She and husband, Mr. Yat K., are farmers who own a four-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. She also sells Khmer cakes. In the rice field, she has the problem of infertile soil. So to improve her rice production, Mrs. Yeth K. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a farmer, and the other a laborer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Alimaa

texts.en:
Alimaa, 56, lives with her son and daughter-in-law and two grandchildren in their own apartment in Darhan, the second biggest city in Mongolia. Her husband passed away 8 years ago. She started her meat trading business in a local market with the working capital of 250,000 MNT in 1996. In the past 12 years, she has managed to increase her money 12 times over. Her business has expanded even a little more now so she is able to buy a certain amount of meat and sell it in her stall in the local market. 

Even though she has a hearing impairment, she has been trying hard to operate a successful business and has managed so far. She is a good-tempered, hard-working woman. Alimaa says, "My dream is to help my son to build up a source of regular income so that he can live without stress all his life." She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to buy and keep more meat that she to sell during Tsagaan Sar, Mongolian traditional New Year.

loans.use: To buy and display more meat for sale

loans.name: Degddorj

texts.en:
Degddorj, 34, is married and lives with his wife and 3 children in a 'ger', Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His oldest daughter attends  a local primary school. They have been living in the same place for 6 years. He has been operating firewood trading business for 2 years. He buys the wood which comes loaded on a big truck and sells it in a local market. He owns a mini truck on which he transports the wood to the market. He transports one truckload of wood with 5 or 6 trips in his own vehicle. 

Degddorj wants to buy a new and bigger truck that he can transport the wood easily and reduce his expenses for petrol. He is eager to enlarge his business so that he can make more profit to support his family without difficulty. He is a hard-working and active person who wants to become an independent businessman in the future. He is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to buy spare parts for his truck and more firewood.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his truck

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en: Mrs. Chroeb U. lives in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. Born in 1970, she is married to Mr. Tet Mea, and has three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, and the youngest one is a farmer. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. She also sells Khmer cakes. Her husband is a construction worker. In the rice field, she has the problem of infertile soil so is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed, pesticide, and have her rice field plowed.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, pesticide, and plow her rice field

loans.name: Badral

texts.en:
Badral, 52, is married and lives with her youngest son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter is married and Badral lives in a 'ger', a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in her daughter's backyard. Her husband is retired and is living temporarily in Zavhan province with their oldest son where he works as a police officer.

Badral has been working as a conductor of a public microbus since 2000. She has owned the microbus since 1999 and she hires a man who drives the it. She is an easy-going and sociable person who says, "I would be able to save more money on what I spend for petrol if I can upgrade the microbus." She is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to renew the engine and tires of her current microbus.

loans.use: To renew the engine and tires of her microbus

loans.name: Phy

texts.en: Mrs. Phy S. A. lives in Chong Angkar village in Takeo province. She was born in 1985 and is a farmer who owns a 1.3-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to help support her family. She also sells mats. Her husband, Mr. Ros Sieng, is a duck breeder who earns money selling duck eggs. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand and so is seeking a loan to buy one thousand ducklings and duck food. She is the mother of two small children.

loans.use: To buy one thousand ducklings and duck food

loans.name: Kul

texts.en: Mrs. Kul K., a villager in Ta Mouk village in Takeo province, is 59 years old. She is a widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, and the other is a security guard. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to support her family. Mrs. Kul K. has the problem of infertile soil so, to improve production, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed, and plow her rice field, too.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, and plow rice field

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Mrs. Yorn P. is a married woman located in Roluos village in Takeo province where she was born in 1986. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ban Tet, is a construction worker. In the rice field, it is time to grow rice, so she needs some money to plant. Mrs. Yorn P. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed, and plow her rice field. She is the mother of two small children.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, and plow her rice field

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon S. is from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Corazon is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Corazon operates a family member's business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Corazon has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Corazon from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta L. has been engaged in rice farming for quite a long time now. Though she is already 62, she is very capable of running a business.

With her 20 years of experience as a farmer, it is her hope that she will be able to expand her harvest and have a bigger farm. In that way, she will be able to help with her family's basic necessities.

She would like to apply for a loan at CEVI. The loan will help her buy fertilizers, chemicals and seeds. By doing this, she thinks she can do something to improve the harvest of her rice farm.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, chemicals and seeds

loans.name: Mok

texts.en:
Mr. Mok T. and his wife, Mrs. Pheap Nget, live in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. They have six children, two of whom are laborers, and three of whom are studying in the local public school.  The youngest one is 4 years old.

The couple are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family.  Mr. Mok T. is also a palm juice collector, and is able to earn some extra money from selling sugar palm. Although they try to work hard, they earn little income. To improve this situation, Mr. Mok T. is requesting a loan to start a new business.  He wants to buy some piglets for breeding and some pig food, and will use the rest of the loan to buy some supplies to collect palm juice.

loans.use: to buy piglets for breeding, and some pig food

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en: Mrs. Sieng N. was born in 1984.  She lives with her husband and 5-year-old child in Roluos village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Phat Tok, is a Khmer cheese seller at a local market, where he is able to earn some extra money for the family. Since her husband’s business is going well, Mrs. Sieng N. wants to expand it. To support this goal, she is seeking a loan to buy more Khmer cheese to resell; she will save the rest of the loan to buy a cow for breeding and start a new business.

loans.use: To buy more Khmer cheese to resell

loans.name: Alegria

texts.en:
Alegria N. wants to “grow to greater heights.” Her goal is to be the leading rice farmer in her area and venture into pigs in the future. This loan will be used to buy rice seeds and fertilizer, and to pay for labor. This way she can plant in time for a better harvest, creating job opportunities for the community.

Drought and financing during planting season are her major challenges. She needs this loan to help her realize her business plan.

Alegria is 48 years old and a mother to four children.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds and fertilizers, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana N. lives in the community of Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She is a rice farmer and she has been doing this business for 10 years.

She has four children. Her eldest is 25 years old. It is her hope to continue her business and earn a bigger income so that she will be able to support her children in paying for books and school fees.

Receiving a loan from CEVI will help her buy fertilizers and seeds. She chose CEVI because of the good program they have in helping farmers like her grow their harvest.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Mrs. Sem T. was born in 1984.  She lives in Prey Kduoch village, in Takeo province, with her husband and two children, who are too small to work or study. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sary Neam, is a construction worker and a duck breeder who earns some money from selling duck eggs to help sustain the family. Since his business is going well, she wants to help him expand it. To support this goal, she is seeking a loan to buy more duck food.

loans.use: to buy more duck food

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn O. owns and manages a small rice field. She has been growing rice for 10 years already. She has two children. Her eldest child is 8 years old. It is her desire to continue to earn her livelihood and be able to support the needs of her children.

Receiving a loan from CEVI will help her buy seeds and fertilizers. In doing this, she will be able to increase her harvest. 

Analyn is 29 years old and she continues to do her best to improve the economic living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Dionesio

texts.en:
Dionesio M. lives in the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. He has 13 years experience as a farmer. He aims to increase his harvest so that he can afford the basic needs of the family. 

He would like to apply for a loan at CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers, chemicals and rice seeds. Through this, he believes he will be able to increase his harvest.

Dionesio is 51 years old and a father to six children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, chemicals and rice seeds

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena R. is a farmer and owns a small parcel of land in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She also grows chickens and pigs in her backyard. It is her dream to grow her business so that she can provide for the needs of her family.

She would like to apply for a loan at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy fertilizers and rice seeds.

The reason for choosing CEVI as her MFI was that she likes the Micro Insurance package of CEVI.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and rice seeds

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea Y. was born in 1983.  She lives in Angk Ta Kob village, in Takeo province, with her family.  Her husband, Mr. Eam Net, is a rice wine maker.  They have two children who are too young to work or study. 

As a pig breeder, Mrs. Sophea Y. is able to earn money to support her family.  But she has a problem because her pigs are too small to sell. To improve this situation, she is seeking a loan to buy more pig food, and to dig a well, which will also be used for her pig-breeding. 

Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: to buy more pig food

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita D. is from the community of Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She is a rice farmer and she has been doing this business for 16 years.

She has three children. Her eldest is 15 years old. It is her hope to continue her business and earn a bigger income. In that way, she will be able to support her children in paying their school fees.

Receiving a loan from CEVI will help her buy fertilizers and seeds. She chose CEVI because of the good program they have in helping farmers like her grow their harvest.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Por

texts.en: Mrs. Por S. is a widow with a child who is employed in a private company. She and her family live in Krang Touch village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. She also breeds pigs, and now she wants to breed a cow, too.  To support this goal, Mrs. Por S. is asking for a loan which, combined with her savings, will allow her to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: En

texts.en:
Mrs. En C. lives in Kandal village in Takeo province. She is a widow with five children, one of whom is a waiter, while another one is employed in a garment factory, and the others are attending local public school. She is a weaver who can earn some money to support her family. 

Currently, she has a problem because her children’s work place is far away from their home. So solve this problem, Mrs. En C. is applying for a loan to buy a new motorbike for her children's transportation.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Enecita

texts.en:
Enecita R. has been engaged in farming for years and has a lot of experience in this business. Currently, she grows rice and root crops. She also grows pigs in her backyard. She is married with seven children. It is her hope to increase her income so that she will be able to attend to the needs in her family. 

Her biggest struggle is that when there are heavy rains, it floods the plants.  She said it is hard to save them from dying especially since her farm is situated in a low-lying area. 

She needs a loan to buy fertilizers and seeds. She chose CEVI because of the good program that they have that really help the small entrepreneurs like her to grow a business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Mrs. Som K. is married to Mr. Chek Nhel; both of them live in Roluos village in Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who own a 1.80-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. She has some problems because it is time to grow her rice, and she needs some money to support her crop. To improve her production, Mrs. Som K. is applying for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and to plow her field. Through this activity, she supports three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory. The other is attending local public school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and plow her field

loans.name: Inocenta

texts.en:
Inocenta Mariscola and her husband are still childless. They are farmers and till a small parcel of land in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. It is their dream to continue their business so that when they have a child they will be able to send their child to school.

Inocenta would like to apply for a loan at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy fertilizers and rice seeds. She chose CEVI because of the Micro Insurance package as the added value in their membership in CEVI.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seeds

loans.name: Julio

texts.en:
Julio V., 44 years old, lives in the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. He has 20 years' experience as a farmer. He hopes to increase his harvest so that he can buy the basic needs of the family.
 
He would like to apply for a loan at CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and rice seeds. In this way, he believes he will be able to expand the size of his harvest.

His reason why he chose CEVI is that he likes the program's micro-insurance coverage. 

Julio is a father with five children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seeds

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en: Mrs. Nhor S. and her family live in Roluos village in Takeo province; she was born in 1976. She is a widow with two children who are both attending local public school. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family and she is a pig breeder, too. She has some problems because it is time to grow rice, and to improve production, Mrs. Nhor S. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and plow her field.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and plow her field

loans.name: Juvelin

texts.en:
Juvelin L. is a mother with two children. Eight years ago, Juvelin had the idea of starting a business growing rice in their field and selling the rice to traders. She  grows her harvest to be able to provide her family with an adequate supply of food, clothing, and other basic needs.

Juvelin has requested a loan from CEVI in order to purchase fertilizers and seeds. She chose CEVI because she likes the micro-insurance package that they have for all borrowers.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Oem

texts.en:
Mrs. Oem S. lives in Phnum Lonteah village in Takeo province and she was born in 1974. She is a food and noodle seller in the local village where she can earn some income to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Than Thoem, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. Although they try to work hard, they can earn only a little income. 

So to improve this situation, Mrs. Oem S. is requesting a loan to buy a cow to breed to start a new business. Any remainder of the money will be added to her savings to buy a new motorbike for family use. She is the mother of one child who is studying in local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow to raise

loans.name: Nicanora

texts.en:
Nicanora M. lives in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She has 13 years of experience as a rice farmer. It is her desire to continue her business and support the needs of her family. Nicanora has a grandchild already and she wants to support her grandchild's education.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the money to buy fertilizers and seeds.

Nicanora is a wife and a passionate mother to her three children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Pin

texts.en: Mrs. Pin P. is 28 years old and lives in Chong Angkar village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice, which she sells to support her family. It is time to plant rice in her rice field. To improve rice production, Mrs. Pin P. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer, and to have someone plow her rice field. Her husband sells mats at a local market, which enables him to earn some money to support his family. This couple supports two children, one of whom is studying in a local public school. The other is 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer, and to plow her rice field

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea B. lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province and she was born in 1972. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. She has some problems because her field is infertile and far away from any irrigation system, and it has a lot of insects. 

So to improve production, Mrs. Chea B. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, pesticide, and plow her rice field. Her husband, Mr. Vorn Khiev, is a policeman. Through these activities, they support four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, but the others are studying in local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, pesticide, and plow her rice field

loans.name: Sar

texts.en:
Mrs. Sar S. lives in Prey Veaeng village in Takeo province and she was born in 1967. She is a  farmer who owns a piece of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sovanna Ret Heng, is a military policeman who can only earn a low salary to support his family. Through these activities, they support three children, one of whom is a waiter, while another one is employed in a hotel, and the third is a student. 

Although they try to work hard, they can earn only a little income. So to improve this situation, Mrs. Sar S. is seeking a loan to buy ten piglets and pig feed for breeding to start a new business. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets and pig feed for breeding

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en:
Rogelia E. is from Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She is engaged in rice farming. She wants to buy more seeds and fertilizer. In that way, she will be able to grow her harvest and earn a better income for her family. She used to grow pigs in her backyard also, but had to focus on rice farming because of financial difficulties.

She is also considering using the loan money to start growing pigs again. She is interested in other income opportunities so that she can save more money for the educational expenses of her children.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa C., 63 years old,  lives in the community of Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She owns a small parcel of farmland and grows rice. It is her biggest dream to have a bigger farm so that she will be better able to support the needs of her family.

Receiving a loan will help her buy fertilizers, chemicals and seeds for her rice farm. She hopes that by doing this, she will be able to increase her harvest.

She likes how CEVI implements its program. She also likes the micro-insurance coverage of CEVI for all its borrowers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, chemicals and seeds

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora D. is a 38-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  'abaca' weaving and hog-raising. She lives in Bugho, Bagalnga, Compostela, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her 'abaca' weaving and hog-raising businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,100. Flora is now borrowing PHP 13,500 so that she can buy frames and stocks for 'abaca'.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Flora aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.  

About NWTF: 

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for 'abaca' (palm-leaf fiber) business

loans.name: Anecia

texts.en:
Anecia V. is a 55-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a food stall (eatery), a general store and a ready-to-wear clothes business.  

She lives in Tak-an, Danao City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her food stall, general store and ready-to-wear clothes businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000.  

Anecia is now borrowing PHP 18,000 so that she can buy rice and spices for her eatery and stocks for the general store. This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Anecia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.  

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operations of the food stall business

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.ru: Джалолов Дилшод проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Ему 35 лет. Женат. Имеет двоих детей. Образование-среднее. Зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Разводит скот у себя дома. Два год как он занимается этим видом деятельности. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Dilshod J. lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube. He's thirty-five years old, married and has two children. He has a high school level of education and makes a living by breeding large cattle near his home. He's been doing this for two years. He's asking for a loan in order to purchase some cattle.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Lucilita

texts.en:
Lucilita Z. is a married woman who lives in Tak-an, Danao City, Cebu. 

She earns her living by operating three business ventures: hog raising, general store and livestock. 

Her husband, Emmanuel, who is 51 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have one child who is 17 years old and is currently going to school.  

Lucilita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lucilita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her eighth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy feed, medicines and vaccines for her pigs and stocks for the general store so that she can continue to save up for her child's education and for future home repairs. 

Lucilita Z. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase feed, medicines and vaccines for the pigs

loans.name: Rosa Lidia

texts.es: Rosa Lidia A. de 68 años habita con su esposo en San Salvador, en casa de un sobrino quien los ha dejado a cargo; ella es una señora mayor pero con un espíritu de superación, por lo cual decidió montar un negocio de comida que esta ubicado en las cercanías de la Universidad de El Salvador, adonde es ayudada por su compañero de vida elaborando alimentos para desayunos y almuerzos que son comercializados entre los alumnos de dicha universidad.Este es un trabajo pesado pero es la única fuente de ingreso para su hogar y es la forma en la que ellos mantienen todas sus necesidades; el préstamo solicitado es  para la compra de más materia prima como arroz, frijoles, maíz y algunos vegetales; además de bebidas y golosinas, también se espera hacer un  mejoramiento de su pequeño negocio que esta hecho de láminas y así poder hacerlo crecer al igual que sus ingresos.
texts.en: Rosa Lidia A. is 68 years old and she lives with her husband in San Salvador. They live in a house belonging to a nephew. She is an older person but she has the will to improve, which is why she has decided to set up a food stall near the university in El Salvador. She gets help by her life partner to make the breakfast and lunch foods that are sold to the students at the university. It is hard work but it is the only source of income for their household and it is the way they are able to provide for all of their needs. This loan will be used to purchase ingredients such as rice, beans, corn, some vegetables, soft drinks, and snacks. They will also carry out some improvements to their small stand. It is made of aluminum sheeting and they want to expand the stall as their earnings grow.

loans.use: To purchas vegetables and basic grains.

loans.name: Teresa Del Carme

texts.es:
Teresa del Carme A. Vda. D. P. D. 34 habita en Cuscatancingo, municipio D. Mejicanos en San Salvador, es dueña D. una tienda y una librería que funciona en su casa adonD. vive con sus dos hijos, hace dos meses su esposo falleció quien ayudaba con los ingresos del hogar, ahora toda esta responsabilidad recae en ella.
Es una persona solidaria con su comunidad y ayuda al hospital San Rafael dando clases D. manualidades. 
EL motivo del préstamo es para su tienda y poder con esto comprar mas productos y víveres, ya que pretenD. agrandarla mas al igual que  agregar mas producto para su librería y tener mas materiales para realizar sus manualidad y seguir ayudando a la comunidad y tener mas ingresos para su familia e hijos que aun se encuentran estudiando.
texts.en:
Teresa del Carmen A. Widow of P. is 34 and she lives in Cuscatancingo, in the municipality of Mejicanos in San Salvador. She is the owner of a convenience and bookstore that she has installed in her house. She lives with her two children. Two months ago her husband passed away and he helped with the expenses for their home. But now that responsibility rests entirely on her. 

She is a person who is very committed to her community, helping the San Rafael hospital by giving artisan classes.

She needs the loan for her store, to purchase more products and groceries. She plans on expanding the store in order to add more products to the bookstore section and to have more crafting articles. She plans on keeping up her community involvement and to earn more income for her family and children who are still in school.

loans.use: To purchase general groceries for resale.

loans.name: Damaris Elizabeth

texts.es: Damaris Elizabeth V. D. H., D. 41 años D. edad resiD. en Ilopango, San Salvador adonD. tiene su negocio D. productos variados, tiene una pequeña tienda en su casa adonD. vive con sus hijos, además D. esto sale  a comercializar otros productos como ropa y zapatos. Es una mujer sencilla pero muy trabajadora y por medio D. su negocio pueD. mantener a la familia, es por esto que solicita un préstamo con el cual espera poder hacer crecer la tienda y surtirla con mas productos como víveres y golosinas ; también comprar más productos D. calidad en cuanto a ropa y zapatos y así  poder tener mas clientes e ingresos.
texts.en: Damaris Elizabeth V. D. Hernandez is 41 years old and lives in Ilopango in San Salvador.  She has a general store located in her house where she lives with her children. She also sells other products such as clothing and shoes. She is a very simple person and she supports her family through this business. She requests a loan in order to expand her store and add variety to her products, including groceries and snacks. She also wishes to purchase more quality clothing and shoes to attract more clients and improve her income.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Zoila Emerita

texts.es:
Zoila Emerita L. D. R. D. 52 años D. edad, vive en San Salvador con su compañero D. vida, es propietaria D. un Restaurante en la zona comercial D. los planes D. Renderos  en San Salvador. Es una mujer activa y con sueños D. superación, al igual que su compañero los dos ayudan en la elaboración D. los alimentos que ahí comercian, ella solicita un préstamo ya que espera poder hacer crecer el negocio y tener mas afluencia D. clientes, además D. la compra D. productos como vegetales, arroz, frijoles, maíz, carne entre otros, para poder realizar nuevos y mejores platos D. comida. 
Con este restaurante ella pueD. mantener su hogar y suplir muchas necesidades en su vida.
texts.en:
Zoila Emerita Lopez D. R. is 52 years old and she lives in San Salvador with her life partner. She is the owner of a restaurant in the commercial region of Planes D. Renderos in San Salvador. She is an active woman with dreams of self-improvement. She and her partner prepare the foods. She requests a loan to make her business grow and to attract new customers. She also needs to purchase products such as vegetables, rice, beans, corn, meats and other ingredients to make new and better meals. 

She is able to support her household with this business and she is able to proviD. for many   every day needs.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase general groceries for resale.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
Peris is a single woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is clothing.

She has operated a tailoring business for the past year, selling from home to her neighbors. Peris faces a major challenge of delayed payments by those who purchase goods on credit. She hopes to open a boutique in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase cloth materials for tailoring. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for tailoring

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth G. is from the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is 46 years old. Elizabeth is married and has five children. Her eldest child is 21 years old while the youngest is only 6. 

To make a living, Elizabeth plants and harvests rice for sale. Elizabeth wishes for her children to finish college and have bright futures.

Elizabeth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. This will be the first loan taken out by Elizabeth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides its clients credit, but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a single man who owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is transportation.

Moses operates a firewood selling business from home. His potential customers are neighbors. Moses faces a major challenge of seasonality. The demand for firewood is high during the rainy season while the demand is lower during the hot summer season.  He hopes to expand his business and generate more income in the future.

With the KES 20,000 he wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of firewood for resale

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira, 43 years old, lives in the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur, with her family. She is married and has 3 children, aged 23, 20 and 9. Elvira and her husband are both farmers. They own the land that they are tilling. They plant and harvest rice crops and then sell them at the market. When free of farming duties, Elvira's husband uses his motorcycle to transport people around their community. Elvira says income from the motorcycle helps in their daily needs.

Elvira joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, medicines and seeds. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elvira from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, medicines and seeds

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
43-year-old Estrella is a rice farmer from the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has 4 kids, aged 15, 13, 10 and 8. All her four kids go to school. Estrella's husband is also a farmer and sidelines as a carpenter. They both work hard to provide their children's needs and sustain their education.

Estrella joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase farming necessities, such as seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Estrella from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Twelwaneko Nabingoola Group

texts.en:
Margret wants a loan to purchase drugs for her clinic. She is 40 years old and a mother of 4 children.  She  owns a clinic, which she has operated for 2 years after attaining training. She faces a problem of lack of medical equipment, like an ultra-sound scanner and a microscope for her clinic, among other equipmentnone the less in future she would like to see her business expand into a hospital.
Margret is a member of Twelwaneko Nabingoola, a group of members who came together for the purpose of improving their household income through access to loans.

loans.use: Buying  drugs for  her clinic

loans.name: Uchi

texts.en:
Uchi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a vegetable-selling business for the past seven years, selling at retail to her neighbours and passersby. Uchi faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the dry summer season, the availability of vegetables is lower and the demand is high. Hence, she is not able to meet the customers' demands in the market. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of fruits and sacks of vegetables for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standard.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of fruits and sacks of vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Guibay

texts.en:
Guibay N. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 50 years old. Guibay is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Guibay owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Guibay has been engaged in farming for 6 years now. 

Guibay joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Guibay is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Guibay from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Paying school fees

loans.name: May's Group

texts.en: May F. is from the village of Disimuray, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 36 years old. May is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. May is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, May raises pigs for fattening and sale. May is just starting this business. In 2010, May joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. May has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. May is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the second loan taken out by May from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Madrilyn

texts.en: Madrilyn V. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 50 years old. Madrilyn is married. To make a living, Madrilyn plants and harvests rice for sale. Madrilyn works hard to help improve her family's living conditions. Madrilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Madrilyn is requesting a new loan of 4,000 Philippines pesos, which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. This will be the first loan taken out by Madrilyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc., (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs that are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth W. lives in the Ntinda neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 8 children, all of whom are in school. Elizabeth has a business of a retail shop. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Elizabeth sells her products in a shop, by means of wholesale/retail. Elizabeth has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy boxes of soap, cartons of salt, boxes of biscuits, and cooking oil. 

She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Elizabeth include transportation and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a car to ease transport and sell wholesale only. Elizabeth lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cans of cooking oil

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar, 20 years old, is from the town of San Francisco. She is married and has a 2-year-old child. To make a living, Maricar owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. At her young age, Maricar is already a responsible mother to her child. She starts to save little by little for her child's future.

Maricar joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricar is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maricar from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en: Gorret is a 35-year-old single woman living in her own permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She has a retail shop and a motorcycle business which she has had for 4 years now and they are still at their boom stage. Her hardship is limited capital.  Her vision is to own a wholesale shop. Gorret needs the loan to purchase soap, cooking oil and maize flour to sell.

loans.use: To purchase soap, cooking oil and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu N. lives in the Makerere Kikoni neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is widowed and has 5 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members, her mother and father.  

Nulu has a business knitting sweaters.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.  Nulu sells her products in a shop, by means of wholesale and retail.  Nulu has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more threads and needles. 

She also generates additional income as a Director of Makerere Aids Widows Development Association.  The main business challenge(s) for Nulu include defaulting by school heads and ever increasing prices of threads.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a registered company for sweaters and to get big tenders from big schools and to own a car.  Nulu lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more threads and needles.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
42-year-old Marites is from the town of San Francisco. She is married and has 5 children, aged 17, 15, 13, 9 and 4. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marites works hard to build her business.

Marites joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, medicines and fertilizers. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marites from CEVI. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, medicines and fertilizers

loans.name: Mendbayar

texts.en:
Mrs. Mendbayar is 40 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her eldest son is a student in a local university and two other boys study in secondary school. 

Mrs.Mendbayar has been running a tailoring business for 12 years. She rents a workshop in one of the busiest areas of Ulaanbaatar and employs three dressmakers. Her husband also helps in her business. Recently they have attended a handbag-making course and besides dresses, they have started making handbags as well. 

During the last 12 years they have accumulated quite a lot of experience in tailoring and have a lots of trusted customers. Mrs. Mendbayar’s sales volume has reached  1500 USD in Mongolian tugrugs a month. Mongolians are looking forward to their Lunar New Year celebration in February 2011 and traditionally they wear national dress on that occasion. Thus Mrs.Mendbayar has  lots of orders to make up. She wants to use the loan to buy more materials and fabrics to make Mongolian national dresses.

loans.use: to buy more materials and fabrics to make Mongolian national dresses

loans.name: Erick

texts.en: Erick O. O. is a single man, with no children yet. He owns a bicycle, which he uses to provide  transport services. His target market is comprised of fish mongers in the area, ice bar suppliers and other local walk-in customers. His business is located in the heart of Kisumu Municipal Fish Market, where there are many people, and therefore, many customers. Erick has been in business for four years now. His business is profitable, but he has major financial constraints. He works very hard to keep his business doing well. He plans to use his loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a motor bike.  He should then be able to do more business for a longer time, since a motor bike is more durable than a bicycle.  He sees himself diversifying into other types of businesses and improving his standard of living. He describes himself as tolerant, observant and persuasive.

loans.use: Motor bike

loans.name: Phiona

texts.en:
Phiona A. lives in the Kawaala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (sisters).    Phiona  has a business selling second-hand clothes.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.  Phiona sells her products in a shop, by means of wholesale/retail.     

Phiona  has requested a loan of 1,200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second hand clothes.    She also generates additional income through rental rooms.The main business challenges for Phiona include transportation and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot of land and also to start selling at wholesale only. Phiona lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is a twenty-two year-old, single male and rents a house in Kasese, Uganda.  He has been in the motorcycle business for the last three years.  He started by riding a bicycle and now rides a motorcycle. His hardship is during the rainy season when it is hard to ride.  His vision is to buy his own motorcycle.  Paul needs credit to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying a motor cycle for transport business.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna, 42 years old, is from the town of San Francisco. She is married and has 6 children. Her eldest child is 15 years old, while the youngest is only 3. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Myrna works hard to sustain her children's education. She says that as their mother, it's her responsibility to give them proper education.

Myrna joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Myrna from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Phanice

texts.en:
Phanice is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She has electricity, but not piped water, in her house. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a grocery shop, selling vegetables, tomatoes and onions. Her customers are neighbours and passersby.  In her business, Phanice faces the major challenges of seasonality and delayed payments by creditors. She hopes to open another business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes and onions for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes and onions for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Perlyn

texts.en:
Perlyn, 45 years old, has 10 kids to feed, clothe and send to school. Her eldest child is 24 years old while the youngest is only 2 years old. Perlyn's husband is also a farmer. They both work hard to earn from their farm. Perlyn also plans to start an additional livelihood to have better income for the family.

Perlyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perlyn is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Perlyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a thirty-one year-old married male, with two children.   He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the bar business for the last year.  He initially started with mandazi (donut-like pastry) baking , saved money, and later started a bar. His hardship is having customers who take a long time to pay.  His vision is to make a big entertainment centre, and to educate children.  Peter needs the loan to buy beer and sodas to sell.

loans.use: To buy beer and sodas to resell.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph O. O. is a married man. His wife is a business lady, and they have no children yet. He owns a bicycle which he uses to provide transport services. His target market is comprised of fish mongers in the area, ice bar suppliers and other local walk-in customers. He is located in the heart of Kisumu Municipal Fish Market, where there are many people and thus, many customers. Joseph has been in business for five years now. His business is profitable.  His major challenges are financial constraints and congestion at the bus terminal, which hinders free and easy movement. He works very hard to keep his business doing well. He plans to use his loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a motor bike. That will allow him to do more business for a longer time, since it is more durable than a bicycle.  He sees himself purchasing a rickshaw to grow his business and improve his standard of living. He describes himself as humble, strong and energetic.

loans.use: Motor bike

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine L. lives in the Kawaala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 6 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members, her grandchildren.  

Christine has a retail shop business.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.  Christine sells her products in a retail shop.  Christine has requested a loan of 1,200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of biscuits, boxes of sweets, boxes of soap, cartons of salt and one liter jerrycans of cooking oil.  She also generates additional income through poultry farming and tailoring.

The main business challenges for Christine include transportation and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot and build rental rooms and also to start selling on wholesale only.  Christine lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food school fees and medication

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of biscuits, boxes of sweets and one liter jerrycans of cooking oil.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is a thirty three year old married woman with five children.  She owns a house in Kasese, Uganda.  She has been selling clothes for the last twelve years.  Her hardship is the lack of capital and her vision is to own a boutique and become a wealthy family with educated children.  Jackline needs the loan to buy clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale.

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly M. lives in the Nabulagala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 4 children, all of whom are in school. Milly has a business of selling clothes. She has been in this business for 8 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Milly sells her products at the market, by means of retail. 

Milly has requested for a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second hand clothes. The main business challenge(s) for Milly include transportation and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot and build her own house and also to start selling on wholesale only. Milly lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes.

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en:
Rosanna, 52 years old, lives with her family in the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She also owns a rice farm that she tills to earn a living. She sells her harvest to the market. Rosanna does her best to support her family financially. She works hard to improve their living conditions.

Rosanna joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosanna is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosanna from CEVI. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Mwena

texts.en:
Mwema is a married woman with eight children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over thirty years, she has operated a water distribution business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Mwema faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the KES 15,000 she wants to start a vegetable business, purchase sacks of vegetables and tomatoes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To start a vegetable business, purchase sacks of vegetables and tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: Eseri

texts.en:
Eseri Nakkazi lives in the Nabulagala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 4 children, all of whom are in school. Eseri has a business of selling charcoal and bunches of bananas. She has been in this business for 4 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Eseri sells her products at the market, by means of retail.    

Eseri has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal and bunches of bananas. The main business challenge(s) for Eseri include transportation and the ever increasing prices of bananas and charcoal. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot and to build rental rooms and also to start selling by wholesale only. Eseri lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity, but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is from the town of San Francisco. She is 44 years and married. She has 5 children aged 21, 16, 13, 5 and 1. To make a living, Veronica owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Veronica also owns and manages a sari-sari store where she sells various kinds of products.

Veronica joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Veronica is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Veronica from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, cooking oil and soft drinks for sale.

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
N. Hadjah lives in the Nabulagala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  Hadjah has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for 8 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Hadjah sells her products at the market, by means of retail.

Hadjah has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenge(s) for Hadjah include seasonality and ever-increasing prices of charcoal.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot and to build rental rooms and also to start selling by wholesale only. Hadjah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Agnetta

texts.en:
Agnetta is a married woman with one child who is still young for school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees and clothing. She has operated a retail shop business for the past five years, selling in a shop to her neighbours and passersby. Agnetta faces a major challenge of competition from other retail shop operators. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, cooking oil and sugar for sale. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, cooking oil and sugar for sale.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: Justine N. lives in the Kawaala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 2 children, one of whom is in school. Justine has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Justine sells her products at the market, by means of retail. Justine has requested for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenge(s) for Justine include seasonality and Defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going to villages of Luwero for charcoal, build her own house. Justine lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah K. lives in the Kawempe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school.  Sarah has a business of selling bananas. She has been in this business for 3 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Sarah sells her products from home, by means of retail. Sarah has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more, bunches of bananas and bags of rice. She also generates additional income through selling rice.

The main business challenge(s) for Sarah include seasonality and ever increasing prices of bananas. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot and build rental rooms and also to start selling on wholesale only.  Sarah lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, rents, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees and clothing. 

She has operated a food stall business, selling at an open air market to her neighbours and passersby. Mwanaidi faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators in her business. 

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of Irish potatoes, cooking oil and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of Irish potatoes, cooking oil and wheat flour.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George O. O. is a married man. His wife is a business-lady and they have seven children aged between twenty-nine years old and fifteen years old. He owns a bicycle which he uses to provide transport services. His target market is comprised of fishmongers in the area, ice bar suppliers and other local walk-in customers. He is located at the heart of Kisumu Municipal Fish Market where there are many people thus many customers to serve. 

George has been in business for seven years now. His business is profitable, but his major challenge is financial constraints. He also says that during the rainy season business is usually low because many people prefer closed vehicles since they are sheltered from cold and rain. He works very hard to keep his business doing well. He plans to use his loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a motorbike which will do more business for a longer time since it is more durable than a bicycle.

He sees himself growing his business and imparting business skills to young people so that they can be able to better their lives. He describes himself as humble, motivated and kind.

loans.use: Motorbike

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees.

She has operated a workshop business for the past five years; her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. Lucia faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business.  She hopes to expand her workshop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase more timber for her workshop business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase more timber  for her workshop

loans.name: Daniela

texts.en:
