Daniela, 55 years old, lives in the the town of San Francisco. She is married and has 3 children aged 29, 23 and 17. Her youngest child is in college now. To make a living, Daniela owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Daniela works hard to provide for her family and sustain her child's college education.

Daniela joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daniela is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, chemicals and fertilizers. This will be the first loan taken out by Daniela from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy seeds, chemicals and fertilizers

loans.name: Namuuntsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs.Namuuntsetseg is 31-year-old divorcee, who lives with her only son Enkhtuvshin 13, in rented apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son attends a local secondary school.  Mrs.Namuuntsetseg is a professional hairdresser. Between 2004-2009 she used to work for a beauty parlor as a hairdresser. 

In 2009 she decided to start her own small business and established a private company. Soon afterward she rented a room and opened  “Namuun” beauty  salon. She hires one beautician and one manicurist in her salon. Since the start her business has flourished and at the moment she has her own trusted permanent customers. 

She is a  very enthusiastic, self-motivated person. Also she said that her communicative character helps in her business a lot. In the future she is planning to expand her business by opening one more branch and employing more people. At the moment, the loan she is requesting will be used to replenish beauty products and to replace old hairdressing and beauty equipment.

loans.use: to replenish beauty products and to replace old hairdressing and beauty equipment

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily lives in the the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur with her family. She is married and has three kids aged 16, 15 and 8. To make a living, Emily owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emily has been engaged in her business for over 3 years.

Emily joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emily is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers. This will be the first loan taken out by Emily from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Atuwezeshe Group

texts.fr: Nyirahabimana M.  est présidente du groupe, âgée de 49 ans, mariée, mère de 9 enfants. Tous étudient dont 3 viennent de finir leurs premiers cycles de graduat à l’université. Son conjoint est un pasteur, serviteur de Dieu dans une église évangélique de la place.  La cliente Nyirahabimana M.  est entrepreneur d’un cafeteria-resto installé  sur  la route principale Goma-Sake-Masisi.  Elle fait également le petit commerce de vente des souliers. Vers 2003, elle commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ au début de  2009. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux produits alimentaires (2 casiers de Fanta, 50 kg de haricots, 20 litres de lait caillé, 10 kg des pommes de terre, 5 kg de viandes, 1 bidon d’huile, sel de cuisine, etc.) et une moitié sera affectée dans le commerce de souliers.  En plus, elle ambitionne devenir commerçante grossiste des souliers. Etant donne que ce dernier offre plus des bénéfices que la cafétéria. La cliente Nyirahabimana M.  remercie Hekima de ses actions pour la promotion des pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Atuwezeshe est constitué de 17 membres mais sur la photo il ya l’excédent de leur collègue dans les affaires. D’où 18 visages visibles sur la photo du groupe.
texts.en: Nyirahabimana M., who is the president of the group, is 49 years old, married and mother to nine children. All of the children are studying and three of them have finished their first graduate cycle at university. Her husband is a pastor and a servant of God in the evangelical church on the square. This customer, Nyirahabimana M., is an entrepreneur with a cafeteria/restaurant on the Goma-Sake-Masisi main road. She also has a small business selling shoes. She began her business around 2003 with her own funds which she got from her husband. Later on, at the beginning of 2009, she benefited from a loan of USD50 from IMF Helima. This new loan will allow her to stock up on new food products (two crates of Fanta, 50kg of beans, 20 litres of curd cheese, 10kg of potatoes, 5kg of meat, one container of oil, kitchen salt, etc.); half of the loan will be allotted to her shoe business. Furthermore, she has an ambition to become a wholesaler trader of shoes, given that this activity generates more profits than the cafeteria. Mrs M. is grateful to Hekima for its actions in helping poor women who are rejected by classic banks. The Atuwezeshe group is made up of 17 members although there are 18 people in the photo.

loans.use: Two crates of Fanta, 50kg of beans, 20 litres of milk, 10kg of potatoes, 5kg of meat, I container of oil, kitchen salt etc.. and 10 pairs of shoes

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and electricity bills.

She has operated a café business for the past five years, selling from home to her neighbours  and passersby. Khadija faces a major challenge of competition from other café operators. She hopes to expand her café and modify it in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she plans to start another business: purchase a water tank to start selling fresh water. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her businesses.

loans.use: To start another business: purchase a water tank to start selling fresh water

loans.name: Svay's Group

texts.en:
In Phngeas village, Takeo Province, four people are members of this group loan.  Mrs. Svay H. is the group president who has been selected by the other members, who will all use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's standard of living.  

She owns a general store in local village where she can sell groceries to earn some profit to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Ngen Ngor, is a farmer who owns 2-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family and he is also a fish breeder too.  Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it.  In order to do this, Mrs. Svay H. is seeking a loan to buy more groceries and to buy more fish food.  She is a mother of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory and the other is a farmer.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet T. lives in the Nabulagala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has one child, who is in school.  Juliet has a business of selling table cloths.  She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days out of every week.  Juliet sells her products door-to-door, by means of wholesale.  Juliet has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of clothing materials and threads.  The main business challenges for Juliet include seasonality and defaulters.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own permanent business premises, to build her own house, and also to educate her child up to university.  Juliet lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of clothing materials and threads for making table cloths

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine N. lives in the Kawaala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (her uncle's children).  

Justine has a pub.  She has been in this business for 7 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Justine sells her products from home, retail.    Justine has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer, sodas, and jerrycans of local gin.  She also generates additional income through plaiting hair.

The main business challenges for Justine include seasonality and defaulters.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked bar, build her own house, and also to educate her children up to university.   Justine lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent and medication.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer, sodas and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William O. O. is twenty-four years old. He is single and does not have any children yet. He owns a motor rickshaw which he uses to provide transport to local people. His target market is comprised of local shoppers at the United Shopping Mall in Kisumu. His business is located near the shopping mall where there are many people thus many customers to serve. 

William has been in business for two years now. His business is profitable, but his major challenge is parking space for motor rickshaw owners who are intimidated by vehicle owners. He works very hard to keep his business doing well. He plans to use his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy spare parts to repair his motor rickshaw to give better service to his customers. He sees himself growing his business, having a family someday, and taking good care of them. He describes himself as talkative, self-reliant and honest.

loans.use: Spare parts

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a married woman with five children, four of whom attend school while one has graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing, and school fees.

For over ten years, she has operated a firewood selling business. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a tailoring business, which contributes another source of income for her family.

Zainab faces major challenges of high cost of transportation and competition from other tailors. She hopes to establish a real estate agency in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for sale and cloth for her tailoring business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of firewood for sale and cloth for her tailoring business

loans.name: Titus

texts.en:
Titus Mwau is a 29 year-old gentleman. He and his wife Priscilla have been blessed with three children between three and eight years old. 

Titus is a poultry farmer while his wife is a housewife who also supports her husband by working on their farm.  He is able to make a profit of about Kshs 10,000 a month from selling the poultry. He has been in this business for 10 years and his clients are from the busy Mlolongo markets.

Titus joined KADET LTD after he was introduced by a friend who was already a client. He has now applied for his second loan which he will use to buy more poultry for resale.  He hopes this investment will give him good profits that he can add to his savings for future use.

He hopes to have a bigger poultry farm where he can sell his chicken at wholesale to retailers. He believes he is hard-working and ambitious and with the capital needed, he can achieve his goals.

loans.use: To buy more chicken to resell

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en:
Agatha M. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has one child who is in school. Agatha has a retail shop.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. 

Agatha sells her products at the market, retail.    Agatha has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of biscuits, reading charts, cigarettes and envelopes. She also generates additional income through working as a cleaner at Makerere University.

The main business challenges for Agatha include holidays and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to sell wholesale, build her own house, and also to educate her child up to university.   Agatha lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of biscuits, reading charts, cigarettes and envelopes

loans.name: Magrete

texts.en:
D. is currently in the business of selling beans, sugar, coffee, etc. She is 35 years old and married to a jobless man, with eight children. Four of them go to school. 

D. took out a loan to stock more beans, sugar, coffee, etc. to sell. She hopes to expand her business  in the future with extra profits from the business.

loans.use: Stock more beans, sugar, coffee, etc. to sell

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en:
Sidi is a married woman with nine children, six of whom graduated from school, while three still attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees.

She has operated a firewood selling business for the past three years. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. Sidi faces a major challenge of competition and high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to sell wholesale in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of firewood for resale

loans.name: Chhoem's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members who live in Damnak Reachea village in Takeo province. Mrs. Chhoem C., born in 1974,  has been selected as the group leader.  The other members will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Chhoem C. is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Sok Sorn, is a construction worker and a fisherman. Mrs. Chhoem C. wants to breed pigs, but her savings is not sufficient, so she is applying for a loan to buy two piglets for breeding to start a new business. 

She is a mother of three children. Two attend the local public school, and the third is 6 years old.

loans.use: To buy two piglets

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is currently in the business of selling fish, oil, etc. She is 45 years old, married to a GoSS worker, with four children. Three of them go to school. Monica took out a loan to stock more fish, oil, etc. to sell. With extra profits from her business, Monica hopes to buy a sheet-iron house in the future.

loans.use: Stock more fish, oil, etc,. to sell

loans.name: Latifa

texts.en:
Latifa L. lives in the Katanga neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has 12 children, nine of whom are in school. Latifa has a little restaurant.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Latifa sells her food at the market.  

Latifa has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes, beef and chicken. She also generates additional income through charcoal sales.

The main business challenges for Latifa include seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations are to sell wholesale and also to educate her children up to university.   Latifa lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches  of bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes, beef and chicken

loans.name: Nida's Group

texts.en:
Nida G. is from the village of Villa Luna, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Nida is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Nida is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Nida owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nida has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Nida is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Nida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana N. lives in the Nakulabye Kiyaye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (mother and children).    

Diana has a beauty salon.  She has been in this business for 8 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.   Diana has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more weaves, braids and cream relaxers.     The main business challenges for Diana include thieves and insufficient capital.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a bridal salon.   

 Diana lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers, weaves (hair extensions),  and braids

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is a widow with four children, three of whom graduated from school, while one still attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent, and clothing.

She has operated an open-air food sales business for the last five years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Juliana faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators. She hopes to expand her business and establish a restaurant in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of Irish potatoes, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of Irish potatoes,  maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Yoksan

texts.en:
Yoksan, 38 years old, is a quiet man. He is married and has four children; Lufrit, who is 16 years old, in the second grade of Senior high school, Once, who is 14 years old, in the second grade of Junior high school, Veni, who is 10 years old, in the fifth grade of Elementary school and Angga, who is 2 and a half years old.

Yoksan used to work in a local shop in Kupang. As a shop worker, his salary was very small. Working for years in the shop didn’t bring any improvement in his family's living standards. The increasing market prices from year to year often distressed him. He really needed some extra income and he couldn’t just rely on his work. After a discussion with his wife, he decided to leave his job. 

Using his own capital, Yoksan started a new business as a fishmonger in Inpres market – a local market in Kupang. He purchases fish from the fisherman in Tablolong, about one hour's drive from Kupang City. Due to the lack of capital, Yoksan cannot increase his business stock to enable him to generate more income. 

Yoksan really wants to improve his business by adding more fish to sell. He is requesting his first individual loan from TLM amounting to IDR 5,000,000. He hopes that TLM is willing to support him by providing the loan.

loans.use: To add more fish to sell

loans.name: Danga

texts.en: Danga is currently in business selling tomatoes, onions, fish, rice, etc. She is 32 years old, married to a working class husband, with three children and all go to school. Danga took out a loan to stock more tomatoes, onions, fish, rice, etc to sell. With extra profits, Danga hopes to expand her business further in the future.

loans.use: Stock more tomatoes, onions, fish, rice, etc. to sell out of her home

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine M. lives in the Makerere neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. Christine    has a restaurant.  She has been in this business for 7 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Christine     sells her food at the market.    

Christine has requested  a loan of 300,000   Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, chicken and 10 kgs of rice. The main business challenges for Christine   include seasonality and defaulters.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot of land and build rental rooms.  

Christine lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, beef, chicken,  and 10 kgs of rice

loans.name: Esly

texts.en:
Esly is a 38-year-old lady. She lives with her husband, Dominggus, and their son, Feto, who is 8 years old and in the third grade of elementary school. People usually call Esly “Uki” as her nickname. She has a kiosk business while her husband is a tailor.  They run the businesses at their house. Elsy and her husband are hard workers; they always work together to meet their family's needs.
  
Esly usually operates her kiosk from 6 a.m. until 9 p.m. She sells variety of snack items, noodles, sugar, cigarettes, detergent, biscuits, soap and many other household needs. She started her kiosk business by using her own money as business capital.  Her money just enabled her to buy a variety of small items. She was only able to generate a meager income from her kiosk. 

Esly joined TLM’s small group lending program for two loan cycles. All loan money was used to add more items to her kiosk. She can generate a better income from the improved business stock. However, she still wants to expand her kiosk by selling basic household needs such as rice, kerosene and gasoline that are not available at her kiosk at the moment. For that reason, she is requesting an individual loan amounting to IDR 3,000,000 from TLM. She definitely believes that loan will help her to improve her business.

loans.use: To add more items to her kiosk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more pork to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more agricultural products to sell and to raise pigs and chickens

loans.name: Thidora

texts.en:
Thidora O S. N. is 29 years old and is married to Elyakim, 33 years old. They have been blessed with four children: Jack, who is nine years old; Aldy, who is seven; Ray, who is five; and Resky, who is three. Three of the children are in school. Thidora and her family live in Taklale village.

To support her husband in meeting their family’s needs, Thidora runs a small kiosk. Her husband provided her with a small amount of money to buy noodles, sugar, coffee, a variety of snacks, cigarettes, detergent, soap, etc. Besides working at home, she loves running her business, as it generates income for her family.

Thidora sees that she could earn more if she could stock her kiosk with a greater variety of goods. Taklale village is situated in a remote area, around thirty kilometers from Kupang City, and most of the community members in the village are farmers. Thidora is requesting a loan amounting to 10,000,000 IDR in order to stock her kiosk with a larger variety of basic household needs such as rice, kerosene, frying oil, etc. She hopes TLM might be able to help her in realizing her plan.

loans.use: To buy household items to sell

loans.name: Nyambayar

texts.en:
Nyambayar, 45, is married and lives with his wife and six children in Darhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. They live in a small house with a 'ger', a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, next to it on the outskirts of the city. They had to build the 'ger' as they are a big family and the house that they own is too small for 8 people. Two of  Nyambayar's children go to university while three others attend secondary school. 

Nyambayar started his clothes retail trading business in 1991 with a working capital of 500,000 MNT by renting an outdoor stall at a local market in Darhan.  In ten years' time, he has managed to enlarge his  business by operating lingerie sales and has increased his working capital 3 times over. He wants to rent an extra stall and expand his business by operating a clothing trading business. 

Nyambayar is a gentle and hard-working person who says, "My desperate wish is to be able to provide my children with the opportunity to get a good education so that in the future they can have a good life. And I would also like to expand my business." He is requesting a loan of 1,800,000 MNT to bring in more goods for sale due to Tsagaan Sar, Mongolian Traditional New Year, as everyone buys gifts for each other.

loans.use: To bring in more goods

loans.name: Muong's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Muong K. has been selected  as group leader by the four members of this group loan in Thnoas village in Takeo province. Each will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve the standard of living of their families. 

She and her husband, Mr. Set Phouch, are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land where they cultivate rice to sell to earn a living.  Mr Set Phouch is also a fisherman and farming laborer. Although they work hard, their income is low. To improve their situation, Mrs. Muong K. is asking for a loan to buy piglets, chickens, and chicken food for breeding to start a new business. This couple does not yet have children.

loans.use: To buy piglets and chickens for breeding

loans.name: Kukat

texts.en:
Kukat S. is a 37-year-old man who is married to Naduari S.; together, they have one child who is 6 months old. Kukat is a livestock trader in the Bissil market, but he also sells his livestock to the Kenya Meat commission and to butchers from the Kajiado and Kitengela areas. This has been his income base since 2009 and he takes home 21,000 Kenyan shillings every month.

Kukat joined KADET LTD after he was introduced to us by one of our credit officers and this is his first loan from KADET. He plans to use the money to buy three cows and 10 goats, which he will sell at a later period. He hopes to make good profits so he can save and buy a pick-up van for transporting his livestock.

He in the future, he hopes to establish a meat-supply company and also start supplying meat to a market called Barma in Nairobi. He believes he is ambitious and focused on achieving his goals.

loans.use: To buy three cows and 10 goats for future resale

loans.name: Dikson

texts.en:
Dikson is a 42-year-old man who is running a “motor-taxi” business.  Dikson lives with his wife and two children in a modest house. The children are Jeanet, aged 17 years, and Richard, who is 15. Both attend school. 

Besides running the motor-taxi business, Dikson also runs a billiard business. He realizes that both of his children will have a huge cost for school, while his motor-taxi business can only provide food for his family. The income from his billiard business is also unstable. These situations sometimes make him distressed and he tries hard to find another way to generate additional income.

Dikson decided to go to a cooperative to get a loan. He wanted to buy a tent and chairs to rent out. The cooperative offers an attractive package, but the interest remains high. Dikson then heard about TLM's program from the field officer and got interested in joining the individual program. He is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 10,000,000. He plans to use the loan to develop his leasing business. He expects the loan could help him in improving his business and he can provide easy access to a tent and chairs for the community around his village when they have a party or other events.

loans.use: To buy a tent and chairs to lease out

loans.name: Raphael Omoso

texts.en:
Raphael Omoso O. is a sole proprietor business man who has been in carpentry work for 19 years in a busy market centre in Kitengela town, and earns a profit margin of KES 10,000 per month. He is 48 years old, married to Loise who is a tailor and this is a source of additional income to the family. They are blessed with two school going children.

Raphael was introduced to KADET LTD by the Credit officer in charge of Kitengela office and he has a very good credit history with KADET and he is applying for his third loan after he paid his previous loans successfully and in time. He intends to use the entire loan amount to open a hardware shop since he has been operating in the open air space. He plans to use the extra income to pay school fee for his children.

He hopes to grow his business and start a carpentry school. Raphael is hard working.

loans.use: To open a hardware shop

loans.name: Markus

texts.en:
Markus is a 48-year-old farmer who is living in Liliba Village. He started farming back in 1994. Besides farming, Markus also works as a builder to generate additional income for his family. 

Markus is the father of three children, namely: Desy, who is 15 and studying in the first grade of Senior high school; George, who is 9 and studying in the third grade of elementary school; and Felix, who is aged 2. As the head of the household, Markus is responsible for the happiness of his family. He would do anything that he can for his family. 

Markus plants mustard greens, 'kangkung' (leafy vegetable), peanuts and corn on his farm. As a farmer, Markus relies on the weather to succeed with his harvest. The erratic weather and limited capital have been a challenge for Markus as a farmer. Sometimes he has to suffer from failure at harvest time because of the bad weather, and he couldn’t replace the damaged plants. 

Markus really wants to improve his business by purchasing more seeds and a water pump to support him in watering the plants. To do so, Markus is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 4,500,000 from TLM. He believes that the loan will bring a positive change to his business.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and water pump

loans.name: Suhbat

texts.en:
Suhbat, 30, is married and lives with his wife and a four-year-old son in a small village in Mongolia. They live in their own winter house. He started his car repair service in 2003. His workshop operates 24 hours a day and it is a busy place as the village is located by the main road between the capital city and the western provinces of Mongolia. He is a hard-working and active person who has enough technical knowledge end experience to run the business successfully. 

Suhbat wants to enlarge the workshop and upgrade his service. In that way, he hopes to  have more regular customers in the future. He is requesting a loan of 500,000 MNT to buy more spare parts that are useful for his workshop.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret K. lives in the Lugala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school.  Margaret  has a restaurant. She has been in this business for 7 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. 

Margaret sells her food from home.    She has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, chicken, cassava, and 10 kgs of rice. The main business challenge for Margaret   is seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot of land and build rental rooms. 

Margaret lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, chicken, rice,  beef, and cassava

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent bills and electricity. 

She has operated a charcoal selling business for the past five years, selling in a shop to her neighbours and passersby. Margaret faces a major challenge of competition from other charcoal sellers in the market. She hopes to supply wholesale in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal and pay for transport costs. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal and pay for transport costs

loans.name: Mendbayar

texts.en:
Mendbayar, 33, is married and lives with his wife and two children in Uvurhangai province in Mongolia. His son attends school and his daughter goes to a kindergarten. They live in a 'ger', a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, and they have been residing at this place for 4 years. 

Mendbayar started making wooden furniture in his backyard in 2007. Mendbayar is a hard-working and active person who is eager to enlarge his business and open his own workshop in the future. He expects more orders than usual due to Tsagaan Sar, the Mongolian traditional New Year, and is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to get more wood and other necessary materials to make more furniture.

loans.use: To get more wood and other necessary materials

loans.name: Naranhuu

texts.en:
Naranhuu, 52, is married and lives with her husband and two children who are both university age. She and her family live in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband works as a guardian for a company. They live in a house and own a store nearby. She opened her grocery store near her house in 2006. She also has a house that is rented and pays 50,000 MNT per month. 

Today Naranhuu's working capital exceeds 600,000 MNT.  She is hard-working and eager to expand her business. Naranhuu purchases her grocery products from the local markets to sell at her shop. She is requesting a loan of 800,000 MNT to buy more meat to sell at her grocery store.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Halako

texts.en:
Halako O. is a married lady. She is the mother of four children whom she loves very much and for whom she works hard every day to ensure she gives them a good education up to the university level. 

Her business is located at Magongo estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. She has been selling shawls for the last three years to local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more shawls to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future and even satisfy the demands of the women of the Magongo area. She describes herself as a very patient lady.

loans.use: Shawls

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou Sangaré est un homme marié de 37 ans et père de 3 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son père dans le quartier Doudounina de Bougouni.
Très tôt, monsieur Seydou Sangaré commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des pièces détachées qu’il a appris dès son jeune âge auprès de son oncle.
Avec une expérience de plus de 15 ans, monsieur Seydou Sangaré maîtrise parfaitement son activité.
Pour agrandir son entreprise il décide de collaborer  avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter des pièces détachées. Il est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice, il envisage agrandir son entreprise et  assurer les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou Sangare is a married man who is 37 years old and the father of 3 children. He lives with his wife and children at his father's house located in the quarter of Doudounina de Bougouni. 

From a very early age Mr. Seydou Sangare started revenue generating activities, especially the buying and selling of spare parts, a business he learned as a young boy from his uncle.  With an experience of 15 years, Mr. Seydou Sangare has perfectly mastered the domain.

In order to expand his business he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). His goal is to purchase spare parts. It is his first experience with Soro Yiriwaso. He supplies himself in Bamako. 

With this loan he expects to earn a monthly income of 40 000 FCFA. 

Through this support he foresees expanding his business and securing the ability to provide for the family's expenses.

loans.use: To purchas spare parts.

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Dramane S. est un homme marié de 36 ans et père de 4 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants à Bougouni dans le quartier Heremakono-Nord.
Après l’école coranique, il est resté longtemps sans emploi. C’est ainsi qu’après une longue réflexion, il décida d’apprendre auprès de son ami le commerce, notamment l’achat et la vente des chaussures et vêtements.
Après avoir eu un petit fond de roulement il décide de mener seul ses activités. Avec  maintenant une expérience de plus de 10 ans, il maîtrise son activité.
Dans le cadre du renforcement de ses activités, il décide d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso qu’il a connu à travers un client.
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter des chaussures et vêtements.
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako(capitale de la république du Mali).
Sa  clientèle  est composé d’hommes et femmes. Les fêtes religieuses et les grandes cérémonies (baptêmes, mariages) sont les périodes où les ventes de ses articles sont intenses.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000 FCFA
 Dans les années à venir il envisage agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramame S. is a married man who is 36 years old and the father of 4 children. He lives with his wife and children in Bougouni, in the Heremakono-Nord quarter. 

After Koranic school, he was left without employment for a long time. After a long period of reflection he decided to learn commerce from his friend, especially the buying and selling of shoes and clothing. 

Once he collected a small working capital he decided to set out in business of his own. Now with an experience spanning 10 years, he has mastered the domain. 

With the goal of strengthening his business he decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner), made known to him by a client. 

With the loan he plans on purchasing shoes and clothing. 

He buys his inventory in Bamako (capital city of the Republic of Mali). 

His clientele is made up men and women. It is during the religious festivals and large ceremonies (baptisms, weddings) that sales for his products are the highest. 

With this loan, he expects to earn a monthly income of 60 000 FCFA. 

In the coming years he expects to expand his store.

loans.use: To purchase shoes and clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 41-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with wife and two young children who are attending school. He has been working as a plumber and painter since 1990. He is the only income provider of the family. He has obtained two Kiva loans and he was an excellent client with payments on time.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a new car so he can make his transportation easier. He expects as a result to increase his productivity and therefore his earnings.

loans.use: to purchase a new car

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Ousmane Sangaré est un homme marié de 41 ans et père de 5 enfants, qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez lui même à Bougouni dans le quartier Dialanicoro.
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus.
Depuis plus de 10 ans il mène l’activité d’achat et la vente des appareils électroniques qu’il appris auprès de son ami. Monsieur Ousmane à une réelle maîtrise de son activité.
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers un autre client de l’institution, il décide alors d’adhérer au programme crédit.
Il compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des appareils électroniques. Ce prêt va lui permettre d’agrandir son entreprise. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de république) du Mali.                                                                                                                                                                       La vente se fait à Bougouni et une partie dans les villages environnants aux marchés hebdomadaires. Il a une clientèle diverse et variée.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 32 000 FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice il envisage construire une maison pour son avenir et ceux de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. Ousame Sangare is a married man who is 41 years old and the father of 5 children. He lives with his wife and children in their own home located in Bougouni, in the Dialanicoro quarter. 

Not having had the opportunity to attend school, from a very young age he started with revenue generating activities. 

For the past 10 years he has had his business buying and selling electronics, a business he learned from a friend. Ousame is a true master of the business. 

Following an introduction to Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) by another client of the organization, he decided to join the credit program.

He plans on using his loan to purchase electronics. This will allow him to increase his business. He makes his purchases in Bamako (capital city of the Republic of Mali). He carries out his sales in Bougouni and in the surrounding villages at the weekly markets.

He has a diverse and varied clientele. 

He expects to earn a monthly income of 32 000 FCFA. 

With this loan he hopes to build a house for the sake of his future and that of his children.

loans.use: To purchase electronics.

loans.name: Francline

texts.en:
Francline is a married man with two children, both of whom are still too young for school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and clothing. 

He has been operating an open-air vegetable stall, selling from home to his neighbours and passersby. Francline faces a major challenge of competition from other vegetable stall operators. He hopes to establish a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000, he wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, onions and tomatoes for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his living standards.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, onions and tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: Soumaila

texts.fr:
Monsieur Soumaïla D. est un homme marié de 34 ans et père de 1 enfant. Il vit avec sa femme et son enfant  chez son père  à Bougouni dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord.
Après l’école coranique, monsieur Soumaïla D. décida de partir en aventure, précisément en Libye à la recherche d’une vie meilleure.
Ses ambitions n’ont pas été réalisées faute de moyen, il décida de retourner au pays précisément à Bougouni auprès de son oncle pour apprendre le commerce notamment la vente d'habits, de chaussures, de slips etc.
Avec une expérience de 5 années, monsieur Soumaïla D. maîtrise son activité.
Dans le but de se renforcer, monsieur Soumaïla D. décide de prendre un prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter divers articles à savoir 30 paires de chaussures et une cinquantaine de complets de prêt à porter. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako,(capitale de la république du Mali). Sa  clientèle est composée d’hommes et femmes. Il est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Avec ce prêt, monsieur Soumaïla D. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA.
 Dans les années à venir il envisage agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Soumaila D. is a married man who is 34 years old and the father of one. He lives with his family and son at his father's house in Bougouni, in the quarter of Heremakono Nord. 

Following Koranic school, Mr. Soumaila D. decided to set out on an adventure, more exactly to Libya in search for a better life. 

His ambitions were not realized for the lack of means, so he decided to return to his country, to Bougouni, to learn from his uncle the business of buying and selling party supplies. 

With a 5-year experience, Mr. Soumaila D. has mastered the business. 

In order to strengthen his business, Mr. Soumaila D. decided to access a loan from Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner), with the goal of purchasing a variety of clothing items, namely 30 pairs of shoes et 50 complete outfits. He makes his purchases in Bamako (capital city of the Republic of Mali). His clientele is made up of men and women. It is his first experience with Soro Yiriwaso. 

With this loan Mr. Soumaila D. expects to earn a monthly income of 70 000 FCFA. 

In the years to come he foresees expanding his store.

loans.use: To purchase party supplies.

loans.name: Souleymane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Souleymane Koné est un célibataire de 26 ans, qui vit chez son père à Bougouni dans le quartier Heremakono-Nord.
Monsieur  Souleymane Koné a vite abandonné l’école moderne pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus. Il a tenté plusieurs activités sans réussite, notamment la vente de tissus.
C’est ainsi qu’il décida d’apprendre la vente des mèches, pommades, crème parfums, déodorants etc... Il a appris cette activité auprès de sa sœur.
Avec une expérience de 5 ans, monsieur Souleymane Koné maîtrise son activité.
Pour agrandir son entreprise, il décida de prendre un prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter, des mèches, pommades, crèmes, vernis parfums et... en grande quantité à Bamako,(capitale de la république du Mali).
Ses clients sont généralement les femmes.  Il est à sa première  expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Avec ce prêt, monsieur Souleymane Koné compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 20 000 FCFA.
 Dans les années à venir il envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Souleymane Kone is a 26-year old single man who lives with his father in Bougouni, in the quarter of Heremakono-Nord.

Mr. Souleymane Kone left school at an early age to start up revenue generating activities. He attempted various businesses without success, including the sale of fabrics. It was then that he decided to take up the sale of hair treatments, skin creams, perfumes, deodorants etc. He learned the business from his sister. 

With a 5-year experience Mr. Souleymane Kone has truly mastered the business. 

In order to expand his business, he decided to access a loan through Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field  Partner) with the goal of purchasing hair treatments, skin creams, nail polish, perfumes etc, in  large quantities in Bamako (capital city of the Republic of Mali). 

His clients are primarily women. It is his first experience with Soro Yiriwaso. 

With this loan Mr. Souleymane Kone expects to earn a monthly income of 20 000 FCFA. In the years to come he expects to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is a married woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and rent bills. 

She has operated a vegetable-stall business for the past two years, selling at retail to her neighbours and passersby. Julia faces a major challenge of competition from other vegetable-stall operators. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, vegetables, and building materials to expand her stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, vegetables, and building materials to expand her stall.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old married man. He is from Lebanon and lives with his wife and two children. He is the only income source for the family. He has been working in furniture making for more than 10 years. He obtained his first Kiva loan and he was a very good client with prompt payments.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to improve his business by getting additional products so he can produce more, allowing him to obtain superior income.

loans.use: improve his business

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Madame Salimata Konaté est une femme mariée de 44 ans et mère de 2 enfants, qui vit avec ses enfants dans le quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni.(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir abandonné l’école en classe de neuvième année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), Salimata décida de s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à la fabrication et vente de l’encens. Elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une amie.
Pour obtenir un fond de roulement consistant pouvant satisfaire ses clients, elle décida de continuer à collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter, des intrants rentrant dans  la fabrication de l’encens. 
Sa production est vendue à Bougouni,  Sikasso et à Bamako. Elle est très sollicitée dans la ville et sa clientèle est composée essentiellement de femmes. Elle s'approvisionne en matières première au marché de Bougouni auprès des grossistes. Elle est à son quatrième prêt et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
La rotation de son activité est très élevée et elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40.000 FCFA.
C’est avec ce bénéfice qu’elle assurera certaines dépenses de la famille et  améliorera d’avantage son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Salimata Konate is a married woman who is 44 years old and the mother of 2 children. She lives with her children in the Torakabougou quarter in Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

After she dropped out of school at the basic grade nine levels (Mali educational system), Salimata decided to take up a revenue generating activity, especially the making and sale of incense. She learned the business from a friend.

In order to have a working capital and to be able to consistently satisfy her clients, she decided to continue on with Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). She will purchase materials she needs in incense production. 

Her products are sold in Bougouni, Sikasso and in Bamako. She is highly solicited in the city and her clientele is primarily women. She purchases her materials in the market in Bougouni from wholesalers. She is on her fourth loan, following the successful repayment of all the previous loans. 

Her business experiences a high rate of sale and she expects to earn a monthly income of 40.000 FCFA. 

With this support she will secure her family's needs and will further improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make incense.

loans.name: Gulnur

texts.en:
Gulnur T. is a 41-year-old villager, who lives in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. She has two children. Her elder son studies in industrial college and her husband works at the local administration. 

Gulnur has been engaged in cattle breeding for 18 years. She started it with the initial capital of 2,000 KGS and managed to develop her farm with the monthly profit of 4,000 KGS.  Gulnur is a really hard-working woman and is known as a purposeful person. Her striving to provide her children with a better life motivate her to apply for a loan of 70,000 KGS for cattle breeding. She will use it to buy one cow, one bull calf and sheep.  With the revenues, Gulnur plans to reconstruct her house.

Kiva's field partner Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas. This leads to increased employment and meets the interests of both clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing, rent bill and school fees.

She has operated an M-pesa shop(mobile banking transfer shop) for the past two years.  Her customers are neighbours and passersby. Elizabeth faces a major challenge of competition from other mobile money transfer operators. She hopes to establish her own retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to pay school fees for her children. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her family living standards.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Laïdou Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Laïdou, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 36 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wela, préfecture de Konobougou ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font la restauration et le commerce de lait et d’habillements.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Laïdou sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du lait, des condiments, des céréales, et des habillements.                                                                          
NAH D. compte acheter, 60 litres du lait avec les peulhs de Barouéli et environnants presque quotidiennement. Elle vend à domicile à l’état frais ou caillé, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses de sa famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five women of the Laidou group are all married and have an average age of 36. They each have 5 children and they live in large traditional extended families in the village of Wela. It is located in the prefecture of Konobougou in the region of Segou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

They are known to each other through family, as neighbors and through friendships. They have various business types including a restaurant, milk sales, and clothing sales. 

The women of the Laidou group are on their first group loan and it will be used to purchase milk, condiments, cereal grains, and articles of clothing. 

Nah D. plans to purchase 60 liters of milk from the Fulani of Baroueli and the surrounding areas, almost on a daily basis. She sells from her house, either fresh or curdled, completing the sales in cash or credit to a clientele made up of women and men. 

She expects to earn a monthly income of 10 000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to supply the needs of the family, and the remaining portion will be used to reinvest back in the business.

loans.use: To purchase fresh milk

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more gallons of red oil, bags of rice, liquor, milk, sardines, candy, biscuits, etc.

loans.name: Ismanbek

texts.en:
Ismanbek S. is 37 years old and lives in Osh city, south of Kyrgyzstan. Ismanbek is known at his local area as an open-hearted and cheerful person, who likes to bring positive emotions to people. Seven years ago, in order to support his family, Ismanbek began his business in selling clothes. He started it with the selling jeans in Russia, but it wasn’t a very profitable activity. Ismanbek redirected his business in selling women’s clothes at the market of Osh. His success as an entrepreneur was achieved due to hard working and strong will in providing his family with all they need. 

Unfortunately, in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the Osh city, Ismanbek lost his business. His small shop was looted and robbed. But Ismanbek, being a very optimistic person, didn’t give up and decided to resume his lost business and continue activities. For this very reason, Ismanbek is applying for a loan of 135,000 KGS, which he needs to restart his activity. With the revenues, Ismanbek plans to improve his living conditions in order to enlarge his family with one more child. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to broaden an assortment of goods

loans.name: Ankadignonye Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Ankadignonye, composé de femmes mariées et célibataire, ont en moyenne 25 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Barouéli, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de parfums, de la pâte d’arachide, du tiéké et d’encens.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Ankadignonye sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des produits alimentaires, de grains de magnonkisseni, des eaux de Cologne, tel HAWA T.                                                                         
Elle s’approvisionne en magnonkisseni et eaux de Cologne à Bamako pour le transformer encens. Elle revend ses produits sur place et au marché de Barouéli au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires  de ses enfants et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Ankadignonye is made up of married and single women, averaging 25 years of age,  and 3 children. They all live in large tradition extended families in the city of Baroueli, located in the prefecture of Baroueli in the Region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

They are known to each other through family, as neighbors and through friendships. They have businesses including perfume sales, peanut butter sales, tiek sales, and incense sales. 

The women of the Ankadignonye group are on their fourth group loan and it will be used to purchase food products, magnonkisseni grains, cologne perfumes, as in the case of Hawa T..

She makes her purchases of magnonkisseni grains and colognes in Bamako to produce incense. She sells her products from her house and at the market in Baroueli, in cash and credit. Her clientele is made up of women and men. 

She expects to earn a monthly income of 30 000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to  cover health care expenses, to purchase food, to pay school fees for her children, and the  remaining portion will be reinvested back into the business.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make incense.

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a widowed woman with six children, two of whom attend school, while four have graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated a vegetable-stall business for the past five years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she operates a clothes shop, which contributes to her other source of income. Rukia faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to sell at wholesale in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, coconuts and tomatoes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, coconuts and tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Djinina, préfecture de Konobougou ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font la restauration et le commerce de condiments, de riz, de laits et des poissons.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire.                                                                     FANTA F. compte acheter un sac de riz et des condiments nécessaires pour la préparation du riz qu’elle vend hebdomadairement au marché de Konobougou, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Danaya are all married and have an average age of 41. They each have 5 children and they live in large traditional extended families in the village of Djinina.  It is located in the prefecture of Konobougou in the Region of Segou (fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali). 

They are known through family and they have businesses including a restaurant and the sale of condiments, rice, milk and fish. 

The women of the Danaya group are on their tenth group loan. Fanta F. plans on purchasing a sack of rice and the condiments she needs to prepare rice. She sells her rice on a weekly basis in the market of Konobougou, completing the sales in cash and credit. Her clientele is made up of women and men. 

She expects to earn a monthly income of 20 000 FCFA, which will be used to repay this loan, to  cover health care expenses, to purchase food, to pay school fees, and to reinvest the remaining  portion in her business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients.

loans.name: Benedetta

texts.en:
Benedetta N. is thirty-six years old, is married, and has two children, aged fourteen years old and five years old. Benedetta’s business is located at a busy market, known as Mukuru Kwa Njenga, and she is served by the Kitengela branch. She owns a tailoring shop and makes clothes such as blouses, dresses, ladies suits, trousers and school uniforms. She serves the local people in this business, which she has been operating for the last ten years. She has managed to provide employment to one person. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well.
Benedetta is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy materials to expand her business. She hopes to grow her business into supplying of ready-made clothes at wholesale. She also sees herself buying a plot of land on which she will build her home. She describes herself as very honest, creative and business-oriented.

loans.use: Materials

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is a married woman with seven children, two of whom graduated from school, while five still attend school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children.

For over twenty years, she has operated a poultry business of laying chickens and broilers. In addition she does farming, growing grains and vegetables for sale, which contributes to her other source of income. Nora faces a major challenge of availability of markets for her produce. Her customers are the local neighbors and passerby. She hopes to become the leading supplier of broilers and layers in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to pay school fees. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to eradicate poverty and improve her social status in the society.

loans.use: To pay for school fees.

loans.name: Djidia Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djidia, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 32 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Konobougou, préfecture de Barouéli ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de parfums, d’habillements et de poissons.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Djidia sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des ingrédients pour la fabrication d’encens, des parfums, des habillements, des poissons.                                                                          
AWA D. compte acheter avec ce prêt, 2 sacs de grains de magnonkisseni, quelques bidons d’eau de Cologne et les autres ingrédients nécessaires à la fabrication d’encens avec les grossistes de Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement en ambulante entre les quartiers de la ville de Konobougou et dans les foires environnantes au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Djidia are all married and are 32 years old on average. They each have 4 children and they live in large extended families in the city of Konobougou, located in the prefecture of Baroueli in the region of Segou (fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali). 

They are known through family, as neighbors and through friendships. They have various business types, including the sale of perfumes, clothing, and fish. 

The women of the Djidia group are on their twelfth group loan and it will be used to purchase materials to make incense and to purchase perfumes, clothing, and fish for resale. 

Awa D. plans to purchase 2 sacks of magnonkisseni grains and a few tubs of cologne and other  materials she needs in order to make incense from the wholesalers in Bamako. She makes her sales on a daily basis itinerantly through the quarters of the city of Konobougou and in at the fairs in the surrounding regions. She completes her sales in cash and credit and her clientele is made up of women and men. 

She expects to earn a monthly income of 35 000 FCFA and it will be used to repay this loan, to contribute to social ceremonies, and to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make incense.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bread and juice

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and wood.

loans.name: Laydou Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Laydou, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Barouéli, préfecture de Barouéli ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce des habillements, des produits cosmétiques et des fruits et légumes.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Laydou sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire. DJENEBA D. s’approvisionne en produits cosmétiques hebdomadairement à Bamako et sur place au marché de Barouéli. Elle effectue ses ventes dans son kiosque au marché de Barouéli, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Laydou solidarity group are married women who average 37 years of age and four children. They all live in extended traditional families in the city of Barouéli, prefecture of Barouéli, in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know one another as neighbors and through ties of kinship and friendship. They sell clothing, cosmetics, fruits and vegetables.

The Laydou members are on their 12th group loan. Djeneba D. gets her cosmetics weekly in Bamako and at the local market of Barouéli. She conducts her sales from a stall at the Barouéli market, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed mainly of women.

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA which she will use to make loan repayments and pay for healthcare, food and tuition, the remainder to be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Sebekai Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sebekai, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 47 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Barouéli, préfecture de Barouéli; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’habillements, de pâtes  d’arachide, de tubercules, de galettes, et de savons.
Les femmes du groupe Sebekai sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des tissus, d’arachide, de tubercule, de savon et de céréales                                                                         
BINTOU S.  s’approvisionne en tissus avec les grossistes au marché de Bamako mensuellement. Elle vend ses habillements à domicile, au marché de Barouéli et  dans les foires environnantes, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 60 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, les frais de contributions des différentes cérémonies civiles, certaine dépenses familiales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce d’habillements.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Sebekai are married and they are 47 years age on average. They have 3 children each and they live in large traditional extended families in the city of Baroueli. It is located in the prefecture of Baroueli in the region of Segou (fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali). 

They are known through family, as neighbors, and through friendships.  They are involved in the sale of clothing, peanut butter, tubers, cookies, and soaps. 

The women of the Sebekai group are on their twelfth group loan and it will be used to purchase fabrics, peanuts, tubers, soaps and cereal grains. 

Bintou S. purchases her fabrics from the wholesalers in the market in Bamako on a monthly basis. She sells clothing from her house and at the market in Baroueli and at the fairs in the surrounding regions. She completes her sales in cash and credit, selling to a clientele made up of women and men. 

She expects to earn a monthly income of 60 000 FCFA which will be used to the payments of this loan, to contribute to various civil ceremonies, to cover certain family expenses and to reinvest back into her clothing business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with six children, three of whom attend school, while three graduated from school. She lives in a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For over fourteen years, she has operated a fish-selling business. Her customers are the local community members. Mwanasha faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the hot summer season, the availability of fish for sale is lower compared to the cold winter season, where the demand is higher. She hopes to educate all her children and expand her business.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to pay school fees for her son. She decided to join Yehu to access loans easily and educate her children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her son.

loans.name: Ankadignongne Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Ankadignongne de l’association Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 38 ans, 3  enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wela, préfecture de Konobougou ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font la restauration et le commerce de galettes, de haricot et des habillements.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Ankadignongne sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des céréales et des tissus.                                                                          
MINATA D. compte acheter quelques mètres de tissus qu’elle coud en draps et califourchon destiné pour les nouvelles mamans en particulier. 
Ce califourchon est un petit pagne utilisé généralement par les femmes mariées comme dessous de pagnes. Il joue en quelque sorte le même rôle que les jupons.  
Elle effectue ses ventes au village et au marché de Konobougou, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, une partie pour prendre en charge les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The eight women of the group named Ankadignongne of the Benkadi association are all married and they have an average age of 38. They each have 3 children and they live in large traditional extended families in the village of Wela, in the Konobougou prefecture, located in the Region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

They are known through family and the have several business types including a restaurant and the sale of cookies, beans, and clothing. 

The women of the Ankadignongne group are on their fifth group loan and it will be used to purchase cereal grains and fabrics. 

Minata D. plans on purchasing several meters of fabric which she makes into sheets and undergarments for new mothers in particular. 

These undergarments are pieces of fabric which are generally used by married women as undergarments. They are used in the same way petticoats.

She makes her sales in her village and at the market in Konobougou, in cash and credit, to a clientele made up of women and men. 

She expects to make a monthly income of 10 000 FCFA which will be used to make the payments for this loan; a portion will be used for health related expenses and to buy food and pay for school fees; the remaining portion will be reinvested back into the business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics.

loans.name: Bendiya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Bendiya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 21 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wela, préfecture de Konobougou; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
